content: Do you use default threading for your messages? Or have you reset to unthreaded? I ask because I am not familiar with how search may use threading. This URL may assist: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: Try this: - on old computer, exit thunderbird and, in file explorer, copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick - on new computer, exit thunderbird and, in file explorer, copy the contents of above copy to the same location. You will be prompted for overwrite, but that's normal. Then start thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks, but I have no idea what a pcr file is. Are you referring to the Mozbackup utility? If so, please do NOT use it. Instead, I suggest exiting thunderbird and copying the profile from c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB stick and, on new PC, with TB not running, copy to same location (but only AFTER thunderbird has been installed. )
creator: davidsk

content: If your old addressbook was within Thunderbird, you can restore it if you still have the old profile using Tools>Import feature. Thunderbird is just an email client, so cannot provide an email address.

content: We have informal contact with Betterbird and the feedback from there is that there are no differences in that aspect of the software. Generally, clearing the profile and reinstalling do more harm than good. If you wish to continue with the TB 32-bit version, I encourage you to post what is happening (although, since this is a business issue, you may prefer to continue with BB to meet business objectives).

creator: willjoe24421

content:
If the emails marked as SPAM are in a spam folder directly under your email, then that's a spam folder on the emails server and probably being marked there, on the email server, and not by Thunderbird.

So you may want to go to the source of the emails and check and see if they're already marked as spam there.

While there, you could WHITE LIST the specific email addresses you know are not spam, so the email server won't mark them as SPAM.

Each email account provider may have different ways of setting up a WHITE LIST, and you may also be able to adjust the sensitivity to the spam. For instance, some email hosts use spam filters like SpamAssassin where you can adjust setting. Thunderbird has a setting to Trust junk mail headers set by..." and you get to enable/disable it as well as select the type of headers it looks for.

You may want to read this... docs.cpanel.net/cpanel/email/spam-filters/

But, as I mentioned, each email service will probably be different.

Spammers Byte. They make us work too hard, forcing us to read through all the junk anyway, just to see if we missed something important.

Good Luck!!
creator: Chicks_Hate_Me

content:
It's working properly here with TB 102/W10/11, as it always has. I don't think it's affected by the underlying OS. Remember, when you create the mailing list, name it and close it, then drop contacts on the list icon in the left pane.

CCleaner is well-known to cause problems if it is allowed to act on TB, although I haven't heard of it being related to the issue of adding contacts to lists.
creator: sfhowes

I have the program CCleaner. I wonder if having it check the registry could be helpful? I used this many times without any problems. Don

content: Are you doing the drag and drop from the address book contact list to the mailing list icon, not the opened window of the mailing list? Try creating a new test address book, add a test contact manually, create a test mailing list in the book, then add the contact by drag and drop (onto the list icon).
creator: sfhowes

content: Nope. Doing it as you say, dragging with a left click, places it in the mailing list AND removes it from the main personal address book. I am not holding down any key and am using the left mouse button.
creator: newspr0

content: Are you sure you're dragging from an address book to a mailing list, and not to another address book? The way it normally works, and works on my setup, is that when a contact is added to a mailing list by drag and drop, it's added to the list, but remains in the address book. If a contact is dragged from one address book to another, the contact is moved, i.e. it is removed from the source and added to the target. Holding Ctrl while dragging and dropping will copy the contact, not move it.
creator: sfhowes
